(ii) If \( u \leq 0 \) in \( \Omega \), then (2.7) holds trivially. Otherwise assume that \( \max_{\Omega} u = u(x_0) > 0 \) and \( x_0 \neq 0, 1 \). Let \( (\alpha, \beta) \) be the largest subinterval of \( \Omega \) containing \( x_0 \) in which \( u > 0 \). We now have \( \tilde{A}u := Au - cu \leq 0 \) in \( (\alpha, \beta) \). Part (i), applied with the operator \( \tilde{A} \) in the interval \( (\alpha, \beta) \), therefore implies \( u(x_0) = \max\{u(\alpha), u(\beta)\} \). But then \( \alpha \) and \( \beta \) could not both be interior points of \( \Omega \), for then either \( u(\alpha) \) or \( u(\beta) \) would be positive, and the interval \( (\alpha, \beta) \) would not be as large as possible with \( u > 0 \). This implies \( u(x_0) = \max\{u(0), u(1)\} \) and hence (2.7). \(\square\)

As a consequence of this theorem we have the following stability estimate with respect to the maximum-norm, where we use the notation of Sect. 1.2.

**Theorem 2.2.** Let \( A \) be as in (2.1) and (2.2). If \( u \in C^2 \), then
\[ \|u\|_C \leq \max\{|u(0)|, |u(1)|\} + C \|Au\|_C. \]

The constant \( C \) depends on the coefficients of \( A \) but not on \( u \).

**Proof.** We shall bound the maxima of \( \pm u \). We set \( \phi(x) = e^{\lambda x} - e^{\lambda x} \) and define the two functions
\[ v_{\pm}(x) = \pm u(x) - \|Au\|_C \phi(x). \]
Since \( \phi \geq 0 \) in \( \Omega \) and \( A\phi = ce^{\lambda} + (a\lambda^2 + (a' - b)\lambda - c)e^{\lambda x} \geq 1 \) in \( \bar{\Omega} \), if \( \lambda > 0 \) is chosen sufficiently large, we have, with such a choice of \( \lambda \),
\[ A v_{\pm} = \pm Au - \|Au\|_C A\phi \leq \pm Au - \|Au\|_C \leq 0 \quad \text{in} \quad \bar{\Omega}. \]

**Theorem 2.1(ii)** therefore yields
\[ \max_{\bar{\Omega}} (v_{\pm}) \leq \max\{v_{\pm}(0), v_{\pm}(1), 0\} \]
\[ \leq \max\{ \pm u(0), \pm u(1), 0\} \leq \max\{|u(0)|, |u(1)|\}, \]
because \( v_{\pm}(x) \leq \pm u(x) \) for all \( x \). Hence,
\[ \max_{\bar{\Omega}} (\pm u) = \max_{\bar{\Omega}} (v_{\pm} + \|Au\|_C \phi) \leq \max_{\bar{\Omega}} (v_{\pm}) + \|Au\|_C \| \phi \|_C \]
\[ \leq \max\{|u(0)|, |u(1)|\} + \|Au\|_C, \quad \text{with} \quad C = \| \phi \|_C, \]
which completes the proof. \(\square\)

From Theorem 2.2 we immediately conclude the uniqueness of a solution of (2.1). In fact, if \( u \) and \( v \) were two solutions, then their difference \( w = u - v \) would satisfy \( Aw = 0, w(0) = w(1) = 0 \), and hence \( \|w\|_C = 0 \), so that \( u = v \).

More generally, if \( u \) and \( v \) are two solutions of (2.1) with right hand sides \( f \) and \( g \) and boundary values \( u_0, u_1 \) and \( v_0, v_1 \), respectively, then
\[ \|u - v\|_C \leq \max\{|u_0 - v_0|, |u_1 - v_1|\} + C \|f - g\|_C. \]
